awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Towards Understanding Typing Privacy: Vulnerabilities and Protection
awd_abstract_narration:
Typing is ubiquitous and plays a significantly important role in the interaction between humans and computer devices. Emerging work has identified a class of attacks that can eavesdrop keystrokes in a non-invasive way without pre-infecting the target computer with malware. Their common underlying principle is that pressing a key on a keyboard causes subtle environmental impacts unique to that key, which can be observed and correlated for all keys. However, those techniques require a training phase to establish the relationship between an observed environmental change and the action of pressing a specific key. Such a training phase is impractical for most attack scenarios. This project identifies a new type of non-invasive keystroke inference technique without requiring the training phase. The goal of this project is to systematically exploit the side effects associated with the typing process via a keyboard, understand new security threats, and design effective defense mechanisms against such attacks.

This research will develop a novel type of typing privacy inference technique targeting various input such as letters and numbers in real-world scenarios and build corresponding defenses to protect typing privacy against those keystroke eavesdropping attacks. The project will provide a much-needed insight into the security risks of typing privacy disclosure, and also substantially improve the security of various computer systems with keyboard interfaces. The results from this research will be openly shared. This project will also offer graduate and undergraduate students opportunities to gain research experience in security and privacy areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to investigate advanced non-invasive keystroke inference techniques and improve the security of various computer systems with keyboard interfaces by creating corresponding defenses to secure typing privacy. Towards this project, we have two main project outcomes. First, we proposed new practical side-channel attacks that can infer keystrokes, without requiring pre-infecting the victim’s device with malware and line-of-sight between the attacker’s device and the target keyboard. Second, we propose defenses to deal with such keystroke inference attacks by disrupting the attacker’s ability to obtain the correct correlation between the typing content and the resulting environmental disturbances. 

We attended mainstream computer conferences to disseminate the research results. These conferences include ACM MobiSys, ACM CCS, ACSAC, RAID, IEEE CNS, EAI MobiQuitous, IEEE MASS, and IEEE CHASE. This award also leads to papers published at top-ranked publication venues, e.g., ACM MobiSys, ACM CCS, ACSAC, RAID, IEEE TDSC, IEEE TMC, and IEEE/ACM ToN. Selected papers are listed below:

1. MotionCompass: Pinpointing Wireless Camera via Motion-Activated Traffic
    Yan He, Qiuye He, Song Fang, and Yao Liu
    ACM Annual International Conference on Mobile Systems, Applications, and Services (MobiSys), 2021.  

2. CommanderGabble: A Universal Attack Against ASR Systems Leveraging Fast Speech
    Zhaohe (John) Zhang, Edwin Yang, and Song Fang
    Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC), 2021.

3. Wireless Training-Free Keystroke Inference Attack and Defense
     Edwin Yang, Song Fang, Ian Markwood, Yao Liu, Shangqing Zhao, Zhuo Lu, and Haojin Zhu
     IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking (ToN), 2022.

4. Proactive Anti-Eavesdropping With Trap Deployment in Wireless Networks
    Qiuye He, Song Fang, Tao Wang, Yao Liu, Shangqing Zhao,and  Zhuo Lu
    IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing (TDSC), 2022.

5. DASK: Driving-Assisted Secret Key Establishment
    Edwin Yang, Song Fang, and Dakun Shen
    IEEE Conference on Communications and Network Security (CNS), 2022.

6. HoneyBreath: An Ambush Tactic Against Wireless Breath Monitoring
    Qiuye He, Edwin Yang, Song Fang, and Shangqing Zhao
    EAI International Conference on Mobile and Ubiquitous Systems: Computing, Networking and Services (MobiQuitous), 2022. (Best Paper Award)

7. WINK: Wireless Inference of Numerical Keystrokes via Zero-Training Spatiotemporal Analysis
    Edwin Yang, Qiuye He, and Song Fang
    ACM Conference on Computer and Communications Security (CCS), 2022.

8. Phantom-CSI Attacks against Wireless Liveness Detection
    Qiuye He and Song Fang
    International Symposium on Research in Attacks, Intrusions and Defenses (RAID), 2023.

9. When Free Tier Becomes Free to Enter: A Non-Intrusive Way to Identify Security Cameras with no Cloud Subscription
    Yan He, Qiuye He, Song Fang, and Yao Liu
    ACM Conference on Computer and Communications Security (CCS), 2023.

10. Precise Wireless Camera Localization Leveraging Traffic-aided Spatial Analysis
    Yan He, Qiuye He, Song Fang, and Yao Liu
    IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing (TMC), 2023.


Last Modified: 05/15/2024
Modified by: Song Fang
